{{primary sources|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox website |name=All Things Digital |logo= |screenshot= |url= {{URL|http://www.allthingsd.com}} |commercial=Yes |location=San Francisco, United States |type=Technology news and analysis |owner=[[Dow Jones]] |author=[[Kara Swisher]]
[[Walt Mossberg]] |launch date=April 16, 2007 |dissolved=December 31, 2013 |current status=Inactive }} '''AllThingsD.com''' was an online publication that specialized in technology and [[startup company]] news, analysis and coverage. It was founded in 2007 as an extension of the annual meetings ''D: All Things Digital Conference'' by [[Kara Swisher]] and [[Walt Mossberg]]. It was a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Dow Jones|Dow Jones & Company Inc.]], and was a member of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''{{-'}}s Digital Network, which includes WSJ.com, [[MarketWatch]], [[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]], and [[SmartMoney]]. In September 2013 Swisher and Mossberg failed to renew their agreement with Dow Jones.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-19/mossberg-to-leave-wall-street-journal-as-allthingsd-talks-fail.html|title=Mossberg to Leave Wall Street Journal as AllThingsD Talks Fail|date=2013-09-19|accessdate=2014-05-26|first1=Edmund|last1=Lee|website=bloomberg.com|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]}} On January 1, 2014, Swisher and Mossberg introduced their own site, ''[[Re/code]]'', based in San Francisco, California.[http://mashable.com/2014/01/01/walt-mossberg-kara-swisher-recode/ Mashable notice] [https://twitter.com/Recode/status/418245503134887936 Twitter notice] accessdate=2014-01-01 The ''AllThingsD'' logo can be spotted during the [[List of Silicon Valley episodes#Season 2 .282015.29|Season 2]] opening credits of the [[HBO]] series [[Silicon Valley (TV series)|''Silicon Valley'']], before being taken down and replaced by the ''[[Re/code]]'' logo as the intro animation progresses.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} ==Site content== AllThingsD.com expanded upon the All Things Digital conference, which was launched in 2003 by Swisher and Mossberg. While the conference quickly became popular and prestigious among the business and technology communities, the number of attendees was limited to approximately 500 people. The web site was set up to “open the conversation to everyone.”[http://allthingsd.com/about/site/ About All Things D] Although the site operates year-round, during each “D” Conference it offers comprehensive and direct coverage of all events and presentations AllThingsD.com focused on news, analysis and opinion on technology, the Internet and media, but considered itself a fusion of diverse media styles, different topics, formats and sources. Initially, the two main features of the site were Kara Swisher's BoomTown blog, and Walt Mossberg's technology product review columns from the Wall Street Journal. Since then, the site had expanded greatly in personnel and focus. Although most of the staff were based in San Francisco, many contributors, including Mossberg, worked primarily in other parts of the United States. ==Featured writers== AllThingsD.com featured nine different writers at the time of closure, where each had their own section of the site, as well as a separate category for other featured writers, both within and outside of the publication: * [[Kara Swisher]]'s BoomTown: Swisher's coverage of digital issues which originally appeared under the same title in the Wall Street Journal, before being published in AllThingsD.com. * [[Walt Mossberg]]'s reviews and personal technology column, also originally run in the Wall Street Journal. * [[Katie Boehret]]'s Digital Solution: a review of consumer technology. * [[John Paczkowski]]'s Digital Daily: an often humorous look at the tech industry and its major personalities. * Peter Kafka's MediaMemo: media and technology coverage. * Liz Gannes' NetworkEffect: reporting with a focus on social networking and the intersection of entertainment and technology. * [[Ina Fried]]'s Mobilized: coverage of wireless issues and devices. * Tricia Duryee's eMoney: reportage on earnings, transactions and financial statistics that move the technology industry. * [[Arik Hesseldahl]]'s NewEnterprise: articles and entries concerning the online business world, covering both hardware and software. * Voices: a portion of AllThingsD.com which featured posts by the site's staff writers, pieces from other Dow Jones properties, and reporters and bloggers from all over the web. ==Conferences== AllThingsD.com also hosted content concerning its D Conferences; besides the annual main event in late Spring, in December 2010 they hosted D: Dive Into Mobile,[http://allthingsd.com/d/dive-into-mobile/?mod=ATD_search/ D: Dive Into Mobile Conference Coverage] the first brand extension of the conference in which representatives from leading mobile device and software producers were interviewed by members of AllThingsD. ==Online commenting== All Things Digital utilized [[Livefyre]] to permit readers to comment on news stories.[http://allthingsd.com/20130330/introducing-livefyre-commenting-at-allthingsd/ Introducing Livefyre Commenting System at AllThingsD - Elizabeth Crane - Social]. AllThingsD (2013-03-30). Retrieved on 2013-07-21. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131221202320/http://allthingsd.com/ All Things Digital] {{News Corporation}} [[Category:All Things Digital| ]] [[Category:2007 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Dow Jones & Company]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2007]] [[Category:American news websites]] [[Category:Technology websites]]

'''Avalanche Canada''' is a non-government, [[non-profit organization]] whose vision is to eliminate [[avalanche]] fatalities and injuries in [[Canada]].<ref>[http://www.avalanche.ca/cac/about/vision-and-mission Avalanche Canada Vision & Mission]</ref> Avalanche Canada is Canada's national public avalanche safety organization. Based in [[Revelstoke, British Columbia]], the organization's aim is to minimize public avalanche risk in avalanche terrain. Avalanche Canada develops and delivers public avalanche forecasts and special public avalanche warnings for many of the mountainous regions of western Canada, free of charge. Avalanche Canada also provides curriculum and support to instructors of recreational '''[http://www.avalanche.ca/cac/training/ast Avalanche Skills Training]''' courses, delivers public avalanche education awareness and education programs, encourages public avalanche research, provides curriculum to teachers and organizations, and acts as a central hub for avalanche information.
The organization was formed in 2004 as the Canadian Avalanche Centre,<ref>{{cite news|title=Out of the snow: The development of the Canadian Avalanche Centre|url=http://www.revelstoketimesreview.com/news/189893431.html|accessdate=26 March 2015|agency=Revelstoke Times Review|date=6 February 2013}}</ref> following a recommendation for the establishment for a national avalanche centre, which was made in a report prepared for the Government of [[British Columbia]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Bhudak Consultants Ltd. |title=Public Avalanche Safety Program Review Prepared for the British Columbia Ministry of Public Safety and Solicitor General |url=http://www.revelstokereview.com/news/189893431.html?mobile=true |accessdate=26 March 2015 |date=23 June 2003 }}</ref> This report was written after 29 people were killed by avalanches in Canada during the winter of 2002-03,<ref>{{cite web|title=Incident Report Database |url=http://old.avalanche.ca/cac/library/incident-report-database/view |website=Avalanche Canada |accessdate=26 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150426134729/http://old.avalanche.ca/cac/library/incident-report-database/view |archivedate=26 April 2015 |df= }}</ref> including seven high school students in the [[2003 Connaught Creek Valley avalanche]].
In October 2014 the Canadian Avalanche Centre officially changed its name to Avalanche Canada.<ref>{{cite news|title=Canadian Avalanche Centre gets new name, funding|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/canadian-avalanche-centre-gets-new-name-funding-1.2786167|accessdate=26 March 2015|agency=CBC News|date=2 October 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://avalanche.ca Avalanche Canada]

}} [[File:EBCproof-8.jpg|alt=Office seen through glass doors|thumb|Avaya office]] '''Avaya''' ({{IPAc-en|ə|ˈ|v|aɪ|.|ə}}) is an American [[multinational corporation|multinational]] [[technology company]] headquartered in [[Santa Clara, California]] that specializes in [[business communication]]s, specifically [[unified communications]] (UC), contact center (CC), and services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/avaya/ |title=Avaya on the Forbes America's Largest Private Companies List|website=Forbes|access-date=2016-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://investors.avaya.com/investors/usa/document/11-13-14_avaya_4q_er_final.pdf |publisher=Avaya|title=company overview}}</ref><ref name="AvayaGlance">{{cite web |url=http://www.avayagov.com/en/documents/avayaataglance.pdf?t=0 |title=Avaya at a glance |publisher=Avaya |accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> Serving organizations at 220,000 customer locations worldwide,[[Avaya#cite note-AvayaGlance-6|<sup>[6]</sup>]] Avaya is the largest pure-play UC and CC company, ranking No. 1 in CC and No. 2 in UC and collaboration. The company had FY17 revenues of $3.3 billion, 78% of which was attributed to software and services.
In late 2017 to early 2018, the company emerged with a new leadership team and a revised strategy based on accelerating open, cloud-first architecture; integrating artificial intelligence (AI), blockchain and emerging technologies, and transforming the business through increased investment in innovation.
== History ==
==={{anchor|Spinoffs & name}}Name=== In 1995, [[Lucent Technologies]] was spun off from AT&T, and Lucent spun off units of its own in an attempt to restructure its struggling operations.[[Avaya#cite note-CNN-7|<sup>[7]</sup>]]
Avaya was then spun off as its own company in 2000. It remained a public company from 2000 to 2007, when it was purchased by [[private equity firm]]s.
In 2001, the Mark Avaya Interaction Center for customer relationship management began, enabling businesses to draw multi-platform call centers to multimedia, multi-site contact centers. A proposed "converged communications" road map focused on the role that applications would play in making communications improve business performance.
On December 15, 2017, it again became a public company, trading under the stock ticker AVYA.<ref name="2018listing" />
==={{anchor|Acquisition and return to private corporation status|2007|2008|2009|2010|2011|2012}}Acquisition and return to private corporation=== In October 2007, Avaya was acquired by two private-equity firms, [[TPG Capital]] and [[Silver Lake Partners]], for $8.2 billion<ref name="Avaya-Nov-2007-8-K">{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/2296/0001193125-07-232187.pdf |title=Avaya, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Nov 1, 2007 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Jan 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=199901276 |title=Investment Firms Pick Up Avaya For $8.2 Billion |publisher=Informationweek.com |date=June 5, 2007 |accessdate=2011-08-18 }} </ref> and the company was delisted on the New York Stock Exchange.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.silverlake.com/Images/Uploads/docs/avaya-close-release-102607new.pdf|title=SILVER LAKE AND TPG CAPITAL COMPLETE ACQUISITION OF AVAYA|last=|first=|date=2007-10-26|website=silverlake.com|publisher=Silver Lake|access-date=2017-01-20}}</ref> The following year, Avaya Speech to Text (enabling voicemail messages to be read on mobile devices or computers) and Avaya Unified Communications (focusing on role-based communications for teleworkers, home agents, small-business mobile workers, branch-office integration, retail stores and branch banking) were introduced, and [[Kevin J. Kennedy|Kevin Kennedy]] became the company's CEO and president.<ref name="Avaya-Jan-2015-23">{{cite web|url=http://www.avaya.com/usa/about-avaya/our-company/leadership/kevin-kennedy/|title=Avaya Leadership |publisher=avaya.com |accessdate =Jan 23, 2015}}</ref>
In 2009, the Avaya Aura for [[Technological convergence|integrated communications]] was introduced, and in December the company acquired Nortel Enterprise's assets for $900 million.<ref name=":0" /> The following year, Avaya was the [[Network convergence|converged-network]] equipment supplier for the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] and [[2010 Winter Paralympics|Paralympics]], and Avaya Aura Contact Center was introduced. In June 2011, Avaya filed an application with the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] to raise up to $1 billion in an [[initial public offering]].<ref name="ipo">{{cite news | url = http://money.cnn.com/2011/06/09/technology/avaya_IPO/ | title = Avaya files for $1 billion IPO | publisher = CNN Money | accessdate = June 9, 2011 | author = Julianne Pepitone | date=June 9, 2011 }} </ref> On October 4, 2011, the company reported that it was acquiring Sipera Systems for its [[session border controller]] (SBC) and [[unified communications]] security applications.<ref name="Avaya-Oct-2011-8-K">{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/175/0001193125-11-263721.pdf |title=Avaya, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Oct 4, 2011 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Jan 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title = Avaya acquires Sipera |author = Larry Hettick |publisher = Network World |date = October 4, 2011 |url = http://www.networkworld.com/newsletters/converg/2011/100311convergence2.html |accessdate = Oct 6, 2011 }}</ref> On October 19, 2011, it was reported that Avaya would buy Aurix.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aurix Acquired by Avaya|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Aurix-Acquired-Avaya-iw-3805680233.html|publisher=Yahoo!}}</ref> Shareholders approved the acquisition of [[Radvision]] for about $230 million on April 30, 2012,<ref name="Avaya-Jun-2012-8-K">{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/2721/0001193125-12-261935.pdf |title=Avaya, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Jun 6, 2012 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Jan 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Avaya Agrees to Acquire RadVision for About $230 Million |author = Shoshanna Solomon |date= 15 March 2012 |url = http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-03-15/avaya-agrees-to-acquire-radvision-for-about-230-million |publisher = Business Week |accessdate = 4 Sep 2012 }} </ref> and the deal closed in June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radvision.com/Corporate/PressCenter/2012/5jun2012_avaya.htm|title=RADVISION Acquired By Avaya|last=|first=|date=2012-06-05|website=radvision.com|publisher=Radvision|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515000856/http://www.radvision.com/support-resources/press-center/05-jun-2012-avaya.htm|archive-date=2014-05-15|accessdate=2012-09-04}}</ref>
==={{anchor|Explored sale and bankruptcy (2016–2017)}}Bankruptcy (2016–2017)=== According to May 2016 news articles<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/05/20/avayas-private-equity-owners-sale/|title=Avaya's Private Equity Owners Explore Sale|date=2016-05-20|website=Fortune|access-date=2016-05-31}}</ref> citing "internal sources", Avaya's [[Private equity firm|private-equity]] owners ([[Silver Lake Partners]] and [[TPG Capital]]) considered a sale of the company valued at $6 to $10 billion including debt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-avaya-m-a-idUSKCN0YB2K3|title=Avaya's private equity owners explore sale: sources|date=May 20, 2016|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref> During the company's [[earnings call]] that month, CEO Kevin Kennedy had confirmed that [[Goldman Sachs]] was helping Avaya evaluate expressions of interest received relative to specific assets and explore other potential opportunities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/edited-transcript-avaya-inc-earnings-151243729.html|title=Edited Transcript of Avaya Inc earnings conference call or presentation 16-May-16 9:00pm GMT|website=www.yahoo.com|access-date=2016-05-31}}</ref> In November, Avaya considered [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|chapter 11 bankruptcy]] while trying to sell its call-center business.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/avaya-weighing-bankruptcy-filing-sale-of-call-center-software-unit-1479941695|title=Avaya Weighing Bankruptcy Filing, Sale of Call-Center Software Unit|date=2016-11-23|publisher=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> On January 19, 2017 Avaya filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11, saying that its foreign operations would be unaffected.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.avaya.com/en/about-avaya/newsroom/news-releases/2017/pr-us-170119a/|title=Avaya Press Release on its decision to file for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy for its US operations|accessdate=Jan 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/avaya-files-for-chapter-11-bankruptcy-protection-2017-01-19|title=Avaya files for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection|last=Linnane|first=Ciara|newspaper=MarketWatch|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-19}}</ref> In its petition, the company listed $5.5 billion in assets and $6.3 billion in debts.<ref>{{Citation | last1 =Moise | first1 =Imani | last2 =Jarzemsky | first2 =Matt | date =January 19, 2017 | title =Avaya Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection | publisher =The Wall Street Journal | publication-place =New York | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/avaya-files-for-chapter-11-bankruptcy-protection-1484848150 | accessdate =January 22, 2017}}</ref>
In an effort to monetize its assets during the bankruptcy period, Avaya announced in March 2017 it would sell its networking business and associated products to [[Extreme Networks]] for $100 million USD. The sale was finalized in July 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/avaya-sells-networking-business-to-extreme-networks-for-100-million/ |title=Avaya sells networking business to Extreme Networks for $100 million |date=March 7, 2017 |accessdate=January 24, 2018 |publisher=ZD Net |author=Natalie Gagliordi}}</ref>
==={{anchor|Explored sale and bankruptcy (2016–2017)}}A New Avaya === In late 2017 to early 2018, the company emerged with a new leadership team under President and CEO Jim Chirico and a revised strategy based on accelerating open, cloud-first architecture; integrating artificial intelligence (AI), blockchain and emerging technologies, and transforming the business through increased investment in innovation. On December 15, 2017, Avaya again became a public company, trading under the stock ticker AVYA.<ref name="2018listing" /> In mid-2018, the company announced that Avaya was positioned as a Leader in the Gartner Magic Quadrant for Unified Communications, the ninth time that the company has been in a Leader position—and was also positioned as a Leader in the Gartner Magic Quadrant for Contact Center Infrastructure for the seventeenth time. Companies in the Leaders quadrant of the Gartner Magic Quadrant are defined as companies that “execute well against their current vision and are well positioned for tomorrow.”
=={{anchor|Purchase of Nortel's Enterprise assets}}Acquisitions== Since 2001, Avaya has sold and acquired several companies, including VPNet Technologies, VISTA Information Technologies, Quintus, RouteScience, Tenovis, Spectel, NimCat Networks, Traverse Networks, Ubiquity Software Corporation, Agile Software NZ Limited, Konftel, Sipera, Aurix, [[Radvision]] and [[Esnatech]].<ref name="Avaya-Jan-2015-22">{{cite web|url=http://www.avaya.com/usa/about-avaya/our-company/history/avaya-acquisitions/ |title=Avaya Acquisitions|publisher=avaya.com |accessdate =Jan 22, 2015}}</ref> Through [[Nortel|Nortel's]] bankruptcy proceedings, assets related to their Enterprise Voice and Data business units were auctioned. Avaya placed a $900 million bid, and was announced as the winner of the assets on September 14, 2009.<ref name="Nortel-Networks-Sep-2009-8-K">{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/128/0001193125-09-191365.pdf |title=Nortel Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Sep 14, 2009 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Jan 19, 2013}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite web | url = http://www.internetnews.com/infra/article.php/3838976/Avaya+Closes+Nortel+Enterprise+Deal+for+900M.htm| title = Avaya Closes Nortel Enterprise Deal for $900M| publisher = internetnews| author = Sean Michael Kerner| date = September 14, 2009| accessdate = Feb 16, 2010}}</ref>
In 2018, Avaya acquired Spoken Communications, a leading innovator in Contact Center as a Service (CCaaS) solutions and customer experience management applications built on conversational artificial intelligence. The Spoken platform accelerates Avaya's growth in cloud-based solutions and provides a reliable and highly scalable cloud platform for customers of all sizes.
=={{anchor|Corporate information|Training|Government business}}Locations and support== {{Expand section|date=February 2017}} Avaya's headquarters are at 4655 Great America Parkway, [[Santa Clara, California]]. The company had offices in over 145 countries in 2011.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.avaya.com/gcm/master-usa/en-us/tasks/connect/contacts/worldwide/worldwide.htm |title = Avaya Worldwide Locator |accessdate = Aug 18, 2011 }}</ref> Avaya sponsors a [[users' group]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.iaug.org/ |title = IAUG|accessdate = Jan 30, 2015}}</ref> and training programs for [[Professional certification (Computer technology)|IT professional certification]] in the use of Avaya's products.<ref name="Avaya Learning">{{cite web |title = Avaya Professional Credential Program |url = https://www.avaya-learning.com/t/CredentialProgram |publisher = Avaya Learning |accessdate = Nov 9, 2014}}</ref> In 1985, Performance Engineering Corporation (later PEC Solutions) was formed to offer technology services to government customers.<ref> {{cite news |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/business/post200/2005/PEC.html |title = PEC Solutions Inc. |publisher = Washington Post 200PEC Solutions Inc. |year = 2005 |accessdate = Apr 1, 2011 }} </ref> On June 6, 2005, [[Nortel]] acquired PEC Solutions to form Nortel PEC Solutions.<ref> {{cite news |url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050607005861/en/Nortel-Completes-Acquisition-PEC-Solutions-Entity-Accelerate |title = Nortel Completes Acquisition of PEC Solutions, Inc. |publisher = Business Wire |date = June 7, 2005 |accessdate = Apr 1, 2011 }} </ref><ref> {{cite news |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/04/26/AR2005042601432.html |title = Nortel to Buy PEC Solutions For $448 Million |work=The Washington Post |date = April 27, 2005 |author = Witte, Griff }} </ref> On January 18, 2006, Nortel PEC Solutions was renamed Nortel Government Solutions.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www2.nortel.com/go/news_detail.jsp?cat_id=-8055&oid=100194159&locale=en-US |title = Nortel PEC Solutions Renamed Nortel Government Solutions |publisher = Nortel |date = January 18, 2006 |accessdate = Apr 1, 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110724132903/http://www2.nortel.com/go/news_detail.jsp?cat_id=-8055&oid=100194159&locale=en-US |archive-date = July 24, 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }}</ref> On December 21, 2009, Avaya acquired Nortel's government business as part of the company's assets sale.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://washingtontechnology.com/articles/2009/12/21/avaya-nortel-merger-government-unit.aspx |title = Avaya/Nortel combination aims for greater growth |publisher = Nortel |date = Dec 21, 2009 |accessdate = Jan 11, 2012 }} </ref><ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.avayagov.com/who-we-are/ |title = Who We Are |publisher = Avaya Government Solutions |accessdate = Apr 1, 2011 }} </ref>
==Patents== Avaya bought Nortel Enterprise and acquired its patents, including:<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.internetnews.com/infra/article.php/3838976/Avaya+Closes+Nortel+Enterprise+Deal+for+900M.htm | title = Avaya Closes Nortel Enterprise Deal for $900M | publisher = Internetnews | date = Sep 14, 2009 | accessdate = Feb 26, 2011 }} </ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.nortel.com/corporate/technology/patents/collateral/list_of_nortel_patents_0506.pdf |title = List of Patents that have {{about|barriers for land vehicles|chains or other barriers to block rivers or harbours|boom (navigational barrier)}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
[[File:Avenida Sáenz y Ferrocarril Belgrano Sur (AGN, 1948).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Manually-operated boom barrier at a [[level crossing]] in [[Buenos Aires]], 1948.]]
A '''boom barrier''', also known as a '''boom gate''', is a bar, or pole pivoted to allow the boom to block vehicular access through a controlled point. Typically the tip of a boom gate rises in a vertical arc to a near vertical position. Boom gates are often [[counterweight]]ed, so the pole is easily tipped. Boom gates are often paired either end to end, or offset appropriately to block traffic in both directions. Some boom gates also have a second arm which hangs 300 to 400 mm below the upper arm when lowered, to increase approach visibility, and which hangs on links so it lies flat with the main boom as the barrier is raised. Some barriers also feature a pivot roughly half way, where as the barrier is raised, the outermost half remains horizontal, with the barrier resembling an upside-down ''L'' when raised.
==Automatic boom barrier== [[File:Bourke-Docker Street level crossing boom gate.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Automatic boom barriers in a level crossing of [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]].]] [[File:Slb+lussen.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Boom barriers in the [[Netherlands]].]]
There are various technologies for an automatic boom barrier. One of them is electro-mechanical, which is widely used due to its reliability. The other technologies are often manufacturer specific. These electro-mechanical devices come with 24VDC drive units which can run continuously without generating heat, so electro-mechanical boom barriers can be operated continuously and in an intensive duty cycle.
===Operation of automatic boom barrier=== An automatic boom barrier can be operated through: # Push button # Remote control # RFID tags / RFID reader # Loop detectors # Any third party access control device
==Usage== Boom gates are typically found at [[Level crossing]]s, [[Bascule bridge|drawbridges]], [[parking|parking facilities]], checkpoints and entrances to restricted areas. They are also the usual method for controlling passage through [[Toll house|toll booth]]s, and can also be found on some [[freeway]] [[entrance ramp]]s which are automatically controlled to drop to restrict traffic in the event of accident cleanup or road closures without the need to dispatch road workers or law enforcement to use a vehicle to block the way. Some boom gates are automatic and powered, others are manually operated. Manual gates are sometimes hung in the manner of a normal gate (i.e. [[hinge]]d horizontally). In some places, boom gates are installed across suburban streets as a [[traffic calming]] measure, preventing through traffic, while allowing [[Authorization|authorised]] [[vehicle]]s such as [[emergency service]]s and [[bus]]es to take advantage of the shorter and more direct route.
==See also== {{Commons category multi|Boom barriers|Level crossing barriers}} * [[Automatic full barriers]] * [[Toll road#Toll collection technology|Toll collection technology]] * [http://www.houstonsystem.com/blog/wide-range-of-boom-barrier-gate-to-suit-your-security-requirements Types of Boom Barrier] {{DEFAULTSORT:Boom Barrier}}

{{Infobox company | name = Computer Aided Development Corporation Limited (Cadcorp)| logo = [[Image:New Cadcorp logo.png]] || type = Private | foundation = [[Bedford]], [[Bedfordshire]] (1991) | location = [[Stevenage]], [[Hertfordshire]], [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] {{coord|51|53|50.70|N|0|12|21.52|W|type:city}} | industry = [[Software]]
[[Geographic information system|Geographic Information Systems (GIS)]] | products = Cadcorp SIS
Cadcorp GeognoSIS
Cadcorp Web Map Layers| homepage = [http://www.cadcorp.com/ www.cadcorp.com] | }} '''Computer Aided Development Corporation Ltd. (Cadcorp)''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] owned and run company established in 1991. Cadcorp has its headquarters in [[Stevenage]], [[Hertfordshire]], [[United Kingdom|U.K.]]. Cadcorp has a network of distributors and value added resellers (VARs) around the world.{{Cite web |url=http://www.cadcorp.com/contact_us_open_gis_systems/global_distributors.htm# |title=Cadcorp Global Distributors and VARs |access-date=2008-03-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080407182421/http://www.cadcorp.com/contact_us_open_gis_systems/global_distributors.htm# |archive-date=2008-04-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Cadcorp is an [[ISO 9001|ISO 9001:2000]] and [[ISO 27000|ISO/IEC 27001:2005]] certified company,{{Cite web |url=http://www.cadcorp.com/press_releases/2007_pr10.htm# |title=Cadcorp ISO 9001 and ISO 27001 certification |access-date=2008-03-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100814032845/http://www.cadcorp.com/press_releases/2007_pr10.htm# |archive-date=2010-08-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }} an [[Oracle Corporation]] partner,{{Cite web |url=http://www.ukoug.org/faqs/directory.jsp?direction=ASC&keyword=&start=11# |title=Oracle Spatial Partners |access-date=2008-03-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071123100225/http://www.ukoug.org/faqs/directory.jsp?direction=ASC&keyword=&start=11# |archive-date=2007-11-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }} a [[Microsoft SQL Server]] Spatial Partner,[http://www.microsoft.com/sqlserver/2008/en/us/spatial-partners.aspx Microsoft Spatial Partners] an [[Ordnance Survey]] Licensed Developer Partner,[http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/manageCompany.do?action=viewCompdetails&sourcePage=search&compId=272 Ordnance Survey Licensed Partner page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606010113/http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/manageCompany.do?action=viewCompdetails&sourcePage=search&compId=272 |date=June 6, 2011 }} and a corporate member of the [[Association for Geographic Information]] (AGI) in the [[United Kingdom|U.K.]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.agi.org.uk/pooled/profiles/BF_COMP/view.asp?Q=BF_COMP_33984# |title=AGI Corporate Members Directory entry |access-date=2008-03-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828152554/http://www.agi.org.uk/pooled/profiles/BF_COMP/view.asp?Q=BF_COMP_33984# |archive-date=2007-08-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }} == History == Cadcorp’s first product was a [[Microsoft Windows]]-based [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] system called Wincad. All rights to the product were sold in 1994. Wincad development and maintenance, carried out latterly by Informatix Inc.,[http://www.informatix.co.jp Informatix Inc., developer of MicroGDS (Wincad)] [[Japan]], through their UK subsidiary[http://www.informatix.co.uk Informatix Software International] under the brand name MicroGDS, was stopped in March 2013{{Cite web|url=http://microgds.co.uk/|title=MicroGDS|website=microgds.co.uk|access-date=2018-04-25}}. After selling Wincad, Cadcorp moved on to developing [[geographic information system|geographic information system (GIS)]] software. The first version of Cadcorp SIS – Spatial Information System ("Cadcorp SIS") was released in 1995. The leadership team successfully completed a [[management buyout]] of the company in May 2015.[http://www.cadcorp.com/news-events/changing-hands-at-cadcorp Changing hands at Cadcorp] == Market == Cadcorp SIS has applications in the following UK markets{{Cite web |url=http://www.cadcorp.com/about_us_ogc/case_studies.htm# |title=Cadcorp case studies |access-date=2008-03-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411111650/http://www.cadcorp.com/about_us_ogc/case_studies.htm# |archive-date=2008-04-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }} * Government (local, municipal and central) * Emergency Services * Land and Property * Insurance * Oil and Gas * Utilities * Maritime * National Mapping Agencies == Open Geospatial Consortium == Cadcorp has been a member{{Cite web|url=http://www.opengeospatial.org/ogc/members|title=OGC Members {{!}} OGC|website=www.opengeospatial.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}} of the [[Open Geospatial Consortium]] (OGC) since 1997. In 2004, Cadcorp’s technical director, Martin Daly was awarded[http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=9498 Kenneth G. Gardels Citation for Martin Daly] the OGC Kenneth G. Gardels Award,[http://www.opengeospatial.org/ogc/awards Kenneth G. Gardels award] made annually to an individual who has made outstanding contributions to advancing the OGC vision of geographic information fully integrated into the worlds information systems. Several versions of the Cadcorp SIS product suite are certified OGC compliant[http://www.opengeospatial.org/resource/products/compliant/#Cadcorp Cadcorp OGC compliance records] in the categories of: * Simple Features for OLE/COM[http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/sfo OGC Simple Features for OLE/COM] * Grid Coverage Service[http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/gc OGC Grid Coverage Service] * Coordinate Transformation Service[http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/ct OGC Coordinate Transformation Service] * [[Web Map Service]] * [[Web Feature Service]] Cadcorp SIS also implements support for: * Web Map Context Documents[http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/wmc OGC Web Map Context] * [[Geography Markup Language]] * [[Simple Features]] * [[Web Coverage Service]] == Product Overview == Cadcorp SIS is available in different forms: * desktop[http://www.cadcorp.com/products/desktop/ Cadcorp desktop products] * server[http://www.cadcorp.com/products/server/ Cadcorp server products] * web mapping[http://www.cadcorp.com/products/web-mapping/ Cadcorp web mapping products] * developer tools[http://www.cadcorp.com/products/developers-tools/ Cadcorp developer tools] * specialised applications[http://www.cadcorp.com/products/specialised-applications/ Cadcorp specialised applications] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.cadcorp.com Cadcorp website] [[Category:GIS companies]] [[Category:Software companies of the United Kingdom]]

'''Certified Payment-Card Industry Security Implementer''' (CPISI) is a certification in the field of [[Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard]] (PCI DSS).
The [[Payment Card Industry Security Standards Council]] (PCI SSC) manages the standard and certifies training organizations. PCI SSC is a collective formed by [[MasterCard]], [[Visa Inc.|Visa]], [[American Express]], [[Japan Credit Bureau|JCB]] and [[Discover Card|Discover]].

Inventions, innovations and firsts made in the county of [[Cheshire]], in [[North West England]].
== Inventions and discoveries == '''[[Polyethylene#History|Polythene]]''' — invented in 1933, at ICI in [[Northwich]].<ref>Rob Sharp, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/polythenes-story-the-accidental-birth-of-plastic-bags-800602.html ''Polythene's story: The accidental birth of plastic bags''], ''The Independent'', 7 Aug 2015</ref><ref>BBC Manchester, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/manchester/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_9042000/9042044.stm "History of the World: the first piece of polythene "], ''BBC'', 7 Aug 2015</ref>
'''[[Hydraulic ram#History|Pulsation Engine]]''' — a precursor to the [[hydraulic ram]], invented by [[John Whitehurst]] in [[Oulton Park]].
'''First observation of extragalactic radio source''' — the Andromeda nebula ([[Andromeda Galaxy|M31]]) made at [[Jodrell Bank]] in 1950 <ref>Jodrell Bank, [http://www.jb.man.ac.uk/history/early.html "The Early History"], ''University of Manchester'', 7 Aug 2015</ref><ref>R. HANBURY BROWN & C. HAZARD, [http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v166/n4230/abs/166901a0.html "Radio-frequency Radiation from the Great Nebula in Andromeda (M.31)."], ''Nature Publishing Group'', 7 Aug 2015</ref>
== Innovations and firsts == '''[[Cheshire cheese|Cheshire Cheese]]''' — there are conflicting accounts of Cheshire Cheese being mentioned in the Domesday Book, and so the first county cheese, or, along with Shropshire Cheese, recorded much later in 1580.<ref>Helen Carter, [https://www.theguardian.com/global/the-northerner/2011/apr/27/cheshire-cheese-revival-sales-plummet "Producers urge a renaissance for Cheshire cheese"], ''The Guardian'', 3 April 2011</ref>
'''UK's first [[Neighbourhood Watch (United Kingdom)|Neighbourhood Watch]]'''
'''[[Timeline of Cheshire history#17th century|First known stagecoach]]''' ran between Birmingham and Holywell via Nantwich and Chester, 1637.
'''First dementia-friendly checkout''' — Tesco supermarket in Chester claimed to be the "First known supermarket to implement a dementia-friendly checkout."<ref>Chester Chronicle, [http://www.chesterchronicle.co.uk/news/chester-cheshire-news/chester-tesco-store-first-implement-9383653 "Chester Tesco store first to implement dementia friendly checkout"], ''Chester Chronicle'', 3 June 2015</ref>

[[Image:Logo-CEEES.png|thumb|right|150px|Logo of the CEEES <ref>[http://www.ceees.org/downloads/brochure/ceeesinfo.pdf Brochure of the CEEES]</ref>]] The '''Confederation of European Environmental Engineering Societies''' (CEEES) was created as a co-operative international organization for information exchange regarding [[environmental engineering]] between the various European societies in this field.<ref>[http://www.gus-ev.de/pdf/ceees_brochur.pdf Confederation of European Environmental Engineering Societies – CEEES], Brochure from the website of Gesellschaft für Umweltsimulation e.V.</ref>
The CEEES maintains an online public discussion forum for the interchange of information.<ref>[http://environmental.org.uk/ceees_forum/ CEEES online Discussion Forum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928015315/http://environmental.org.uk/ceees_forum/ |date=2007-09-28 }}</ref>
==The member societies of the CEEES==
As of 2012, these were the twelve member societies of the CEEES:
*[[Italy]]: Associazione Italia Tecnici Prove Ambientali (AITPA) *[[France]]: Association pour le Développement des Sciences et Techniques de l'Environnement (ASTE) *[[Belgium]]: Belgian Society of Mechanical and Environmental Engineering (BSMEE) *[[Germany]]: Gesellschaft für Umweltsimulation (GUS) *[[Finland]]: Finnish Society of Environmental Engineering (KOTEL) *[[Czech Republic]]: National Association of Czech Environmental Engineers (NACEI) *[[Austria]]: Österreichische Gesellschaft für Umweltsimulation (ÖGUS) *[[Netherlands]]: PLatform Omgevings Technologie (PLOT) *[[United Kingdom]]: Society of Environmental Engineers (SEE) *[[Sweden]]: Swedish Environmental Engineering Society (SEES) *[[Portugal]]: Sociedade Portuguesa de Simulacao Ambiental e Aveliaca de Riscos (SOPSAR) *[[Switzerland]]: Swiss Society for Environmental Engineering (SSEE)
Each member society successively holds the presidency and the secretariat for a period of two years.
==Technical Advisory Boards==
The CEEES has three major Technical Advisory Boards:
*Mechanical Environments: The aim of this board is to advance methodologies and technologies for quantifying, describing and simulating mechanical environmental conditions experienced by mechanical equipment during its useful life. *Climatic and Atmospheric Pollution Effects: The aim of this board is the study of the climatic and atmospheric pollution effects on materials and mechanical equipment. *Reliability and Environmental Stress Screening: The aim of this board is the study how the environmental effects the reliability of equipment.
==Publications==
These are some of the publications of the CEEES:<ref>[http://environment-ecology.com/reports/267-publications-of-the-confederation-of-european-environmental-engineering-societies.html Publications of The Confederation of European Environmental Engineering Societies]. From the website of Environment-Ecology.</ref>
* ''A Bibliography on Transportation Environment'', ISSN 1104-6341, published by the Swedish Packaging Research Institute (Packforsk) in 1994. * ''Synthesis of an ESS-Survey at the European Level'', ISSN 1104-6341, published by the Swiss Society for Environmental Engineering (SSEE) in 1998. * ''List of Technical Documents Dedicated or Related to ESS'', {{ISBN|91-974043-0-6}}, published by the Swiss Society for Environmental Engineering (SSEE) in 1998. * ''Climatic and Air Pollution Effects on Material and Equipment'',ISBN No. 978-3-9806167-2-0, published by Gesellschaft für Umweltsimulation (GUS) in 1999. * ''Natural and Artificial Ageing of Polymers'', 1st European Weathering Symposium, Prague. {{ISBN|3-9808382-5-0}}, published by Gesellschaft für Umweltsimulation (GUS) in 2004 * ''Natural and Artificial Ageing of Polymers'', 2nd European Weathering Symposium, Gothenburg. {{ISBN|3-9808382-9-3}}, published by Gesellschaft für Umweltsimulation (GUS) in 2005 * ''Ultrafine Particles – Key in the Issue of Particulate Matter?'', 18th European Federation of Clean Air (EFCA) International Symposium, published by the Karlsruhe Research Center (Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe FZK) in 2007. * ''Natural and Artificial Ageing of Polymers'', 3rd European Weathering Symposium, Kraków. ISBN No. 978-3-9810472-3-3, published by GUS in 2005. * ''Reliability - For A Mature Product From The Beginning Of Useful Life. The Different Type Of Tests And Their Impact On Product Reliability''. ISSN 1104-6341, published online by CEEES in 2009.
==See also==

{{redirect|Beauty school|the band|Beauty School (band)|the song by [[Deftones]]|Diamond Eyes}} '''Cosmetology''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] {{lang|grc|κοσμητικός}}, ''kosmētikos'', "beautifying";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cosmetic|title=Cosmetic - Definition of cosmetic by Merriam-Webster|publisher=|accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref> and {{lang|grc|-λογία}}, ''[[wiktionary:-logia|-logia]]'') is the study and application of [[beauty treatment]]. Branches of specialty include [[hairstyle|hairstyling]], [[skin care]], [[cosmetics]], [[manicures]]/[[pedicure]]s, non permanent hair removal such as [[waxing]] and [[Sugaring (epilation)|sugaring]] and permanent hair removal processes such as [[electrology]] and [[Intense Pulsed Light]] (IPL).
== Cosmetology specialties ==
===Cosmetologist=== Cosmetologists are trained and licensed to perform cosmetic treatments to the hair, skin, and nails.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cosmetologist|title=Definition of COSMETOLOGIST|website=www.merriam-webster.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-27}}</ref> This can be expanded into multiple parts including cutting and chemically treating hair, chemical hair removal without a sharp blade, fashion trends, wigs, nails and skin care, skin and hair analysis; relaxation techniques including head, neck, scalp, hand and feet basic massage and aroma therapies; plus ability to expertly apply makeup applications to cover or promote and can expand into further specialties such as reflexology; theatrical applications; cosmetics and others as listed below. A cosmetologist is someone who is an expert in the care of hair and makeup as well as skincare and beauty products. They can also offer other services such as coloring, extensions, perms and straightening. Cosmetologists help their clients improve on or acquire a certain look by applying advance trending aesthetic applications. Hair stylists often style hair for weddings, proms, and other special events in addition to routine hair styling.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
===Hair colorist === A hair color specialist, aka hair colorist, specializes in the modification of natural hair color utilizing various application methods while using a colorant product from a professional company. In the US, some colorists are qualified through the American Board of Certified Hair Colorists. This designation is used to recognize colorists that have a greater level of competency in the industry through a written exam and a practical exam. A hair color specialist's duties might include, but are not limited to, basic color applications like covering grey and lightening or darkening natural hair color. A color specialist also has the ability to perform corrective color applications and create special effects using foiling techniques or any other advanced color application methods.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
=== Shampoo technician === A shampoo technician shampoos and conditions a client's hair in preparation for the hair stylist. This is generally an apprentice position and a first step for many just out of cosmetology school.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
===Aesthetician{{anchor|Esthetician}}=== Aestheticians are licensed professionals who are experts in maintaining and improving skin.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schmaling|first=Susanne|title=Miladys Aesthetician Series: Aging Skin|year=2011|publisher=Cengage Publishing|location=Clifton Park NY|isbn=978-1-4354-9614-9|page=4}}</ref> An aesthetician's general scope of practice is limited to the [[epidermis (skin)|epidermis]] (the outer layer of skin).<ref>Milady Standards Fundamentals Esthetics{{full citation needed|date=October 2017}}</ref> Aestheticians work in many different environments such as salons, med spas, day spas, skin care clinics, and private practices. Aestheticians may also specialize in treatments such as [[microdermabrasion]], microcurrent (also known as non-surgical "face lifts"), [[cosmetic electrotherapy]] treatments ([[galvanic current]], high frequency), LED (light emitting diode) treatments, ultrasound/ultrasonic (low level), and mechanical massage (vacuum and g8 vibratory).<ref>Milady Standard Advanced Esthetics{{full citation needed|date=October 2017}}</ref><ref>Professional BeautyTherapy 3rd Edition{{full citation needed|date=October 2017}}</ref>
The aesthetician may undergo special training for treatments such as laser hair removal, permanent makeup application, light chemical peels, eyelash extensions, and [[electrology]]. In the US, aestheticians must be licensed in the state in which they are working and are governed by the cosmetology board requirements of that state. Aestheticians must complete a minimum 260–1500 hours of training and pass both a written and hands-on exam in order to be licensed in a given state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascpskincare.com/become/boardinfo.php|title=About Membership|publisher=|accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref> [[Utah]], [[Virginia]] and [[Washington (state)|Washington]] are the only states at this time to adopt the Master Esthetician License.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skininc.com/spabusiness/regulations/Washington-States-New-Licensing-Law-for-Estheticians-204165191.html|title=Washington State's New Licensing Law for Estheticians|work=Skin Inc.|accessdate=30 June 2015}}</ref> Additional post graduate training is sometimes required when specializing in areas such as medical esthetics (working in a doctor's office). Estheticians work under a [[dermatologist]]’s supervision only when employed by the dermatologist's practice. Aestheticians treat a wide variety of skin issues that are cosmetic in nature, such as mild [[Acne vulgaris|acne]], [[hyperpigmentation]], and aging skin; therefore, clients with skin disease and disorders are referred to a dermatologist or other medical professional. Aestheticians are also referred to as beauticians in North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/us/aesthetician}}</ref>
==Occupational hazards== Many chemicals in salon products pose potential health risks. Examples of hazardous chemicals found in common treatments (e.g. hair coloring, straightening, perms, relaxers, keratin treatments, Brazilian Blowouts, and nail treatments) include dibutyl phthalate, formaldehyde, lye (sodium hydroxide), ammonia, and coal tar. Allergies and dermatitis have forced approximately 20% of hairdressers to stop practicing their profession.<ref>[http://digitalcommons.ilr.cornell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1006&context=manuals Reducing chemical exposure is a continual career investment]</ref>
In the beauty and cosmetology industries, some of the products used in hair dyes and nail applications contain chemicals that have been shown to have adverse health effects for cosmetologists.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.fct.2015.04.011 |pmid=25865937 |title=Screening-level human health risk assessment of toluene and dibutyl phthalate in nail lacquers |journal=Food and Chemical Toxicology |volume=81 |pages=46–53 |year=2015 |last1=Kopelovich |first1=Luda |last2=Perez |first2=Angela L |last3=Jacobs |first3=Neva |last4=Mendelsohn |first4=Emma |last5=Keenan |first5=James J }}</ref> A chemical combination known as the toxic trio is often part of the ingredient list in nail polish, hair dyes, and nail polish removers. The toxic trio consists of formaldehyde, toluene and dibutyl phthalate (DBP).<ref>{{cite journal |first1=John D. |last1=Breskey |title=California again leading the way: cosmetics safety and worker health |journal=Californian Journal of Health Promotion |year=2013 |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=vi–viii |url=http://www.cjhp.org/volume11Issue1_2013/documents/BreskeyJ_Editorial_vi-viii.pdf }}</ref> DBP is frequently found in nail polish and is used as a binder to increase the amount of time the polish stays on the nail. Toluene is an industrial solvent and is usually in nail polish removers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nail Polish sales slow after years of growth: are customers finally tired of the trend? |url=http://style.time.com/2013/07/26/nail-polish-sales-slow-after-years-of-growth/ }}</ref> Formaldehyde can be found in a variety of beauty products but is generally found in hair straightening products and hair dyes as well as in some nail polishes. Each chemical member of the toxic trio has independently been found to have adverse reproductive effects in humans, so there concern that the presence of all three chemicals in cosmetologist supplies could pose a detrimental health risk for cosmetologists.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
===Demographics of the cosmetology industry=== As a profession, cosmetology is predominantly female, most of whom are of reproductive age.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/occmed/kqp017 |pmid=19270042 |title=Work as a hairdresser and cosmetologist and adverse pregnancy outcomes |journal=Occupational Medicine |volume=59 |issue=3 |pages=180–4 |year=2009 |last1=Halliday-Bell |first1=J. A |last2=Gissler |first2=M |last3=Jaakkola |first3=J. J. K }}</ref> There are more than one million women registered and licensed as cosmetologists in the United States and roughly several million more work as hairdressers.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.reprotox.2010.01.011 |pmid=20132878 |title=Health outcomes of children born to cosmetologists compared to children of women in other occupations |journal=Reproductive Toxicology |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages=361–5 |year=2010 |last1=Gallicchio |first1=Lisa |last2=Miller |first2=Susan R |last3=Greene |first3=Teresa |last4=Zacur |first4=Howard |last5=Flaws |first5=Jodi A }}</ref> Among cosmetologists, hairdressers and nail technicians make up a large part of the working population. Many cosmetologists begin their careers before reproductive age and before family planning, which may put them at higher risk for reproductive health effects from exposure to workplace cosmetology chemicals.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal |doi=10.3928/21650799-20131121-01 |pmid=24328919 |pmc=4260452 |title=Occupational Chemical Exposures Among Cosmetologists: Risk of Reproductive Disorders |journal=Workplace Health & Safety |volume=61 |issue=12 |pages=522–8; quiz 529 |year=2013 |author1=Pak |first1=V. M |last2=Powers |first2=M |last3=Liu |first3=J }}</ref>
In the United States the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is responsible for public safety regarding cosmetic products and the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act regulates these products.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.fct.2003.11.003 |pmid=15019177 |title=Toxicity and human health risk of hair dyes |journal=Food and Chemical Toxicology |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=517–43 |year=2004 |last1=Nohynek |first1=Gerhard J |last2=Fautz |first2=Rolf |last3=Benech-Kieffer |first3=Florence |last4=Toutain |first4=Herve }}</ref> The Cosmetic Ingredient Review (CIR) utilizes an "Expert Panel" to review available data on cosmetic ingredients and determine whether or not chemical ingredients in cosmetic products are safe to use considering how they are currently utilized.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.fct.2010.11.022 |pmid=21111022 |title=Safety of botanical ingredients in personal care products/cosmetics |journal=Food and Chemical Toxicology |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=324–41 |year=2011 |last1=Antignac |first1=Eric |last2=Nohynek |first2=Gerhard J |last3=Re |first3=Thomas |last4=Clouzeau |first4=Jacques |last5=Toutain |first5=Hervé }}</ref> However, this protocol is only helpful if applied to all cosmetology workplaces in the United States.
An investigation carried out by the Environmental Working Group revealed only 11% of more than 10,000 cosmetic ingredients documented by the FDA were evaluated in a CIR review.<ref name=pmid17940905>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10903-007-9084-4 |pmid=17940905 |title=Results from a Community-based Occupational Health Survey of Vietnamese-American Nail Salon Workers |journal=[[Journal of Immigrant and Minority Health]] |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=353–61 |year=2007 |last1=Roelofs |first1=Cora |last2=Azaroff |first2=Lenore S |last3=Holcroft |first3=Christina |last4=Nguyen |first4=Huong |last5=Doan |first5=Tam }}</ref> Research studies have shown that although "toxicological considerations play an increasingly significant role in product formulation; reproductive risks are not typically taken into account.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.5271/sjweh.46 |pmid=8571088 |title=Reproductive disorders due to chemical exposure among hairdressers |journal=Scandinavian Journal of Work, Environment & Health |volume=21 |issue=5 |pages=325–34 |year=1995 |last1=Kersemaekers |first1=WM |last2=Roeleveld |first2=Nel |last3=Zielhuis |first3=Gerhard A }}</ref> It is also known that, "more than 9,000 chemicals are found in cosmetic products".<ref name="ReferenceA"/> airdressers use a wide range of products containing chemicals. "Hair dyes represent the largest segment of chemical products in the hair market today. As such, they are the main source of chemical exposure among hairdressers".<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10661-008-0338-y |pmid=18483770 |title=Airborne exposure to chemical substances in hairdresser salons |journal=Environmental Monitoring and Assessment |volume=153 |issue=1–4 |pages=83–93 |year=2008 |last1=Ronda |first1=Elena |last2=Hollund |first2=Bjorg Eli |last3=Moen |first3=Bente E }}</ref>
===Chemical exposures===
===Toluene===
Toluene is a clear, water insoluble liquid with a distinct and pungent smell,<ref name="ATSDR Toluene">{{cite web |title=Public Health Statement for Toluene |date=January 21, 2015 |publisher=Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry |url=https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/phs/phs.asp?id=159&tid=29 }}</ref> similar to paint thinners. Toluene is found in cosmetic products like nail polish, nail glue, and hair dyes <ref>Nail Care Products https://www.fda.gov/cosmetics/productsingredients/products/ucm127068.htm</ref> and is widely used as an industrial solvent and is used to make fingernail polishes, lacquers, adhesives, rubber, and paint thinners. It is used in the production of benzene, gasoline, nylon, plastics, and polyurethane.<ref name="ATSDR Toluene"/> Toluene can be found on cosmetic labels under the names, benzene, toluol, phenylmethane, methylbenzene.
Toluene enters the environment when materials like fingernail polish, paints, paint thinners, and adhesives are used. It rapidly mixes with the air and individuals who work with paint, lacquer, or dyes have greater exposures to toluene via dermal and respiratory routes.<ref name="ATSDR Toluene"/> Toluene inhalation during pregnancy has led to neonatal effects, including intrauterine growth retardation, premature delivery, congenital malformations, and postnatal developmental retardation.<ref name=pmid1954933>{{cite journal |pmid=1954933 |pmc=1567945 |year=1991 |author1=Donald |first1=J. M |title=Reproductive and developmental toxicity of toluene: A review |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=94 |pages=237–44 |last2=Hooper |first2=K |last3=Hopenhayn-Rich |first3=C |doi=10.2307/3431317}}</ref>
====Dibutyl phthalate==== [[Dibutyl phthalate]] (DBP) is a manufactured chemical used as a plasticizer. It's used to make plastics more flexible and can be found in paints, glue, insect repellents, hair spray, nail polish, and rocket fuel.<ref>Di-n-butyl Phthalate https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/substances/toxsubstance.asp?toxid=167</ref> Due to its flexibility and film forming properties, making it an ideal ingredient in cosmetics and cosmetology products. DBP is mainly used in nail products as a solvent for dyes and as a plasticizer that prevents nail polishes from becoming brittle, but is also used in hair sprays, to help avoid stiffness by allowing them to form a flexible film on the hair.<ref>Phthalates https://www.fda.gov/cosmetics/productsingredients/ingredients/ucm128250.htm</ref>
When a nail polish is applied, it dries to the nail as some of the other chemicals volatilize and DBP remains on the nail, making the polish less brittle and apt to crack. The chemical may not only be absorbed through the nail, but through the skin as well. When nail-polished hands are washed, small amounts of DBP can leach out of the polish and come into contact with the skin. The application of nail polish can also provide an opportunity for skin absorption.<ref>[http://www.ewg.org/reports/beautysecrets Environmental Working Group - Does a common chemical in nail polish pose risks to human health?]</ref>
Dibutyl phthalate has been linked to reproductive issues in humans if the mother is exposed while pregnant and has been banned for use by the European Union<ref name="ReferenceB"/> and certain phthalate esters have been shown to cause reproductive toxicity in animal models.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=21241635 |url=http://journal.scconline.org/abstracts/cc2010/cc061n06/p00457-p00466.html |year=2010 |last1=Hubinger |first1=Jean C. |title=A survey of phthalate esters in consumer cosmetic products |journal=Journal of Cosmetic Science |volume=61 |issue=6 |pages=457–65 }}</ref>
====Formaldehyde==== [[Formaldehyde]] is a colorless, strong smelling liquid that is highly volatile, making exposure to both workers and clients potentially unhealthy. Both the Environmental Protection Agency ([[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]]) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration ([[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]]) classify [[formaldehyde]] as a human carcinogen. Formaldehyde has been linked to nasal and lung cancer, with possible links to brain cancer and leukemia.<ref>[http://www.osha.gov/SLTC/formaldehyde/index.html United States Department of Labor – Safety and Health Topics – Formaldehyde]</ref>
Growing evidence reveals that various popular hair-smoothing treatments contain formaldehyde and release formaldehyde as a gas.Formaldehyde is a common ingredient in Brazilian blowouts, Cadiveu, and Keratin Complete Smoothing Therapies. Four laboratories in California, Oregon, and Canada, confirmed a popular hair straightening treatment, the [[Brazilian hair straightening|Brazilian Blowout]], contained between 4% and 12% formaldehyde. Oregon OSHA demonstrated that other keratin-based hair smoothing products also contain formaldehyde, with concentrations from 1% to 7%.<ref name="CDPH Brazilian Blowout">{{cite web |url=https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CCDPHP/DEODC/OHB/CSCP/CDPH%20Document%20Library/BrazilianBlowoutQA.pdf |publisher=California Department of Public Health |title=Q&A: Brazilian Blowout & other hair smoothing salon treatments |date=March 3, 2011 }}</ref>
Formaldehyde may be present in hair smoothing solutions or as a vapor in the air. Stylists and clients may inhale formaldehyde as a gas or a vapor into the lungs and respiratory tract. Formaldehyde vapor can also make contact with mucous membranes in the eyes, nose, or throat. Formaldehyde solutions may be absorbed through the skin during the application process of liquid hair straighteners. Solutions of formaldehyde can release formaldehyde gas at room temperature and heating such solutions can speed up this process. Exposure often occurs when heat is applied to the treatment, via blow drying and flat ironing.<ref name="CDPH Brazilian Blowout"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://osha.oregon.gov/OSHAPubs/hazard/2993-26.pdf |publisher=Oregon OSHA |title=Hair smoothing products and formaldehyde |date=October 28, 2010 }}</ref>
Stylists and clients have reported acute health problems while using or after using certain hair smoothing treatments containing formaldehyde. Reported problems include nose-bleeds, burning eyes and throat, skin irritation and asthma attacks. Other symptoms related to formaldehyde exposure include watery eyes; runny nose; burning sensation or irritation in the eyes, nose, and throat; dry and sore throat; respiratory tract irritation; coughing; chest pain; shortness of breath; wheezing; loss of sense of smell; headaches; and fatigue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://osha.oregon.gov/OSHAPubs/reports/keratin-based-hair-smoothing-report.pdf |publisher=Oregon OSHA and CROET |title='Keratin-Based' Hair Smoothing Products And the Presence of Formaldehyde |date=October 29, 2010 }}</ref>
===Reproductive health and birth defects of the toxic trio=== The presence of Formaldehyde, phthalates, and toluene (the toxic trio) in the work environment play a role in the risk of reproductive health effects for cosmetologists. Studies shows that there is a significant increase in premature birth and an increased risk of pregnancy disorders when hairdressers were compared to a referent group of teachers and salesclerks where the only occupational difference were exposure to the toxic trio.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1539/joh.15-0068-RA |pmid=26269279 |title=Reproductive disorders in hairdressers and cosmetologists: A meta-analytical approach |journal=Journal of Occupational Health |volume=57 |issue=6 |pages=485–96 |year=2015 |last1=Henrotin |first1=Jean-Bernard |last2=Picot |first2=Cyndie |last3=Bouslama |first3=Myriam |last4=Collot-Fertey |first4=Dorothée |last5=Radauceanu |first5=Anca |last6=Labro |first6=Marie-Thérèse |last7=Larroque |first7=Béatrice |last8=Roudot |first8=Alain-Claude |last9=Sater |first9=Nessryne |last10=Elhkim |first10=Mostafa Ould |last11=Lafon |first11=Dominique }}</ref> Hairdressers and cosmetologists have a slightly increased risk of having an infant with small gestational age. Reproductive disorders in relation to low birth weight were examined and found an increased risk of having infant with low birth weight; three of these studies showed a significant increase.<ref name=pmid19608567>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/humrep/dep252 |pmid=19608567 |title=Premature ovarian failure among hairdressers |journal=Human Reproduction |volume=24 |issue=10 |pages=2636–41 |year=2009 |last1=Gallicchio |first1=L |last2=Miller |first2=S |last3=Greene |first3=T |last4=Zacur |first4=H |last5=Flaws |first5=JA }}</ref>
Case studies on toluene exposures have found increased incidences of urogenital, gastrointestinal, and cardiac anomalies among children of mothers who were exposed to organic solvents, such as toluene.<ref name=pmid1954933/> Associations were found between pregnant women who inhaled Formaldehyd, phthalates, and toluene and adverse reproductive outcomes such as intrauterine growth retardation and premature delivery.<ref name=pmid1954933/> Hairdressers report premature ovarian failure five times more frequently than women in non-cosmetologist occupations.<ref name=pmid19608567/>
==Regulation of cosmetics in the U.S.== In the United States, the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) defines cosmetics as “articles intended to be rubbed, poured, sprinkled, or sprayed on, introduced into, or otherwise applied to the human body…for cleansing, beautifying promoting attractiveness, or altering appearance”.<ref>Is It a Cosmetic, a Drug, or Both? (Or Is It Soap?) Is It a Cosmetic, a Drug, or Both? (Or Is It Soap?). (2017). Fda.gov. Retrieved 26 October 2017, from https://www.fda.gov/Cosmetics/GuidanceRegulation/LawsRegulations/ucm074201.htm </ref> Products such as nail polish, hair coloring, straightening formulas, and shampoos fall under this definition of cosmetics. In the U.S., the FDA does not mandate premarket approval for cosmetic ingredients or products, with the exception of color. Additionally, the FDA is not legally responsible for cosmetic product or ingredient safety and does not have the authority to require manufactures to submit their safety data to the FDA.<ref name="FDA Prohibited Restricted Ingredients">{{cite web |title=Prohibited & Restricted Ingredients |date=January 26, 2015 |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration |url=https://www.fda.gov/cosmetics/guidanceregulation/lawsregulations/ucm127406.htm }}</ref> Instead, the cosmetic manufacturer is legally responsible for correctly labeling and producing their products with safe ingredients. U.S. cosmetic companies are also not required to register their product or ingredients with the FDA as registration is purely voluntary. The FDA cannot legally order a recall of cosmetic products in the U.S. even if they have been shown to have poor health outcomes. A product recall relies on the cosmetic manufacturer is completely voluntary.<ref name="FDA Prohibited Restricted Ingredients"/>
In contrast, the European Union requires cosmetic products to undergo premarket safety testing and requires mandatory cosmetology product and ingredient registration.<ref> Cosmetics - Growth - European Commission. (2017). Growth. Retrieved 26 October 2017, from https://ec.europa.eu/growth/sectors/cosmetics_en</ref> In general, the European Union approaches cosmetics and their production under the precautionary principle. The EU has banned 1,328 chemicals from use in cosmetics and does not permit animal testing for cosmetics.<ref>Anon (2017). Eur-lex.europa.eu. Retrieved 26 October 2017, from http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:342:0059:0209:EN:PDF</ref>
===OSHA requirements regarding formaldehyde===
OSHA requires manufacturers, importers, and distributors to identify formaldehyde on any product that contains more than 0.1% formaldehyde (as a gas or in a solution), or if the product can release formaldehyde at concentrations greater than 0.1 parts per million ([[Parts per million|ppm]]). Safety data sheets ([[safety d888ata sheet|SDS]]) must also accompany the product and kept on premises with the product at all times. The SDS must explain why a chemical in the product is hazardous, how it is harmful, how workers can protect themselves, and what they should do in an emergency.<ref name="osha.gov">[http://www.osha.gov/SLTC/formaldehyde/hazard_alert.html United States Department of Labor – Hazard Alert - Hair Smoothing Products That Could Release Formaldehyde]</ref>
Salon owners and stylists are advised to look closely at the hair smoothing products they use (read product labels and SDS sheets) to see if they contain methylene glycol, formalin, methylene oxide, paraform, formic aldehyde, methanal, oxomethane, oxymethylene, or CAS Number 50-00-0. According to OSHA's Formaldehyde standard, a product containing any of these names should be treated as a product containing formaldehyde. OSHA's Hazard Communication standard ([[Right to know|Right to Know]]) states that salon owners and other employers' must have a SDS for products containing hazardous chemicals. If salon owners or other employers decide to use products that contain or release formaldehyde they are required to follow the guidelines in OSHA's Formaldehyde standard.<ref name="osha.gov"/>
The Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA), is responsible for inspections of worker health and safety. It is estimated 375,000 nail technicians work in nail salons in the United States. Yet in 2005, OSHA inspected only 18 nail salons because businesses are exempt from inspection if they have 10 employees or less.<ref name=pmid17940905/> According to the Asian American Resource Workshop, Vietnamese nail salon workers hold 40% of nail technician licenses in the United States.<ref name=Hoang2006>{{cite web |last1=Hoang |first1=Diu |year=2006 |title=Vietnamese American Nail Salons |publisher=Immigration Research and Information |url=http://www.immigrationresearch-info.org/vietnamese-american-nail-salons }}</ref> "It's long hours, low hourly pay, and fierce competition from every corner of the block" and with such fierce competition between businesses, salaries are reduced even further.<ref name=Hoang2006/> As a result, a majority of these immigrants are subject to low socioeconomic status; which subsequently reduces opportunity to be educated about the occupational chemicals they are exposed to in the workplace and reduces opportunity to seek health care if adverse health effects are experienced from chemical exposure.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
==Cosmetology careers== In the United States, whether planning to study cosmetology or specialize in a specific area, each state has different requirements that must be fulfilled before obtaining a license.
For example, the State of Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulations requires each candidate to complete their hours through a licensed cosmetology school program where new skills are taught and learned such as [[hair coloring]], styling, hair cutting and the usage of hazardous chemicals. After completing the minimum hours to obtain a state license, an online examination is required and is submitted via mail with other supported documentation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.idfpr.com/profs/cosmo.asp|title=State of Illinois {{!}} Department of Financial & Professional Regulation|website=www.idfpr.com|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref> Bureau of Labor Statics states that the median salary for a licensed cosmetologist is $28,770 as of May 2015.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes395012.htm#nat|title=Hairdressers, Hairstylists, and Cosmetologists|website=www.bls.gov|access-date=2016-08-01}}</ref> Illinois Metropolitan Division Areas, [[Chicago]]-[[Naperville, Illinois|Naperville]]-[[Arlington Heights, Illinois|Arlington Heights]] has one of the highest employment rates with an annual rate of $27,750.<ref name=":1" /> Being a licensed cosmetologist opens the door to becoming self-employed and working at High-End Salons. As a licensed cosmetologist, each has the option to choose which salon fits best to work in but a self-employed salon will bring more income as long as having the right business plan for it to succeed. Each candidate registering for a salon has to obtain a certificate of registration and present all required paperwork with the FEIN, Federal employer identification number to [[Illinois Department of Labor]].<ref name=":0" />

'''EC Regulation 1223/2009 on cosmetics''' sets binding requirements for [[cosmetic products]] that have been made available on the market within the [[European Union]]. Manufacturers of products that fall under the category or cosmetics are required to abide by this regulation as they prepare their initial release of products and while continuing to sell said products within the Member States of the EU.<ref name="Turner-EC1223/2009">{{cite web|last1=Turner|first1=Dawn M.|title=Understanding EC Regulation 1223/2009 on cosmetics|url=https://www.desjardin.fr/blog/ec-regulation-1223/2009-on-cosmetics|publisher=Desjardin|accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref>

'''EU BANS THREE FRAGRANCE ALLERGENS USED IN COSMETIC PRODUCTS'''
'''THE EUROPEAN COMMISSION HAS PUBLISHED THE REGULATION (EU) 2017/1410, BANNING THE USE OF THREE FRAGRANCE ALLERGENS, HICC (CAS NO. 51414-25-6/ 31906-04-4), ATRANOL (CAS NO. 526-37-4) AND CHLOROATRANOL (CAS NO. 57074-21-2).'''
Currently,
HICC is regulated in entry 79 under '''Annex III to Regulation (EC) No. 1223/2009'''. When its presence exceeds 0.001% in leave-on products, and 0.01% in rinse-off products, it must be declared in the list of ingredients. Atranol and chloroatranol are natural components of oak tree moss and tree moss extracts, they are neither restricted nor prohibited under current regulation.
European Commission first considered adopting SCCS opinion SCCS/1459/11 on June 26-27, 2012. The opinion concluded these fragrance allergens had caused the highest number of contact allergies cases in recent years. The European Commission has now updated the regulation to prohibit the use of these three fragrance allergens.
